p: Gender is known to be a factor that significantly impacts migration experiences [ 11]. As a result of economic insecurity, limited education, linguistic and cultural barriers, migrants most often present late to care. These factors may also place migrants, especially women, at risk for acquiring HIV-1 infection [ 12]. Women immigrating from countries with high rates of HIV-1 infection, unaware of their HIV status, are also at higher risk for delivering infants with perinatally acquired HIV-1 [ 13], especially as in Israel, where universal HIV-1 prenatal screening is not mandatory [ 14].
